abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Transport Rehabilitation
            Project for Togo were as follows: outcomes were
            unsatisfactory, project sustainability was unlikely, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            deficient. Some lessons learned included: the supervision of
            the project seems to have been critical for project
            implementation. Important factors that would have supported
            project success are: appropriate technical advice;
            continuity of Bank staff, consistent follow-up, timely
            response to the Borrower and cooperation with the Borrower
            team. Technical Assistance (TA) should be short-term and
            focused on beneficiary needs. Likewise training should
            correspond to beneficiary-identified needs, and be provided
            on site, whenever possible, by qualified trainers. The
            reforms subject to political risks were not implemented
            under the project. These reforms should be put as up-front
            conditions. The time needed to change attitudes and
            approaches should be taken into account during the
            preparation so that reforms may be implemented before Board
            presentation. The unreliability of Togolese counterpart
            funding should be considered as a major risk for any
            project, and all precautions should be taken to mitigate
            this risk. Agreements reached during negotiations are not a
            sufficient answer. This issue should be continuously
            addressed during project preparation and implementation and
            appropriate actions should be taken in case of default.

docna.cdata!:
Togo - Transport Rehabilitation Project :
            Credit 1861 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Togo - Transport Rehabilitation
            Project : Credit 1861 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Transport Rehabilitation Project
            seeks to assist the Government in rehabilitating and
            maintaining essential transport infrastructure and in
            improving sectoral efficiency, including the strengthening
            of existing institutions as well as the adoption of sound
            policy and regulatory measures.  Subject to annual reviews
            and updatings, the project covers the Government's
            1988-1990 total sectoral expenditure program.  The program
            places particular emphasis on road maintenance, including
            increased funding and institutional improvements, selective
            road rehabilitation of national and feeder roads, and
            upgrading of a limited number of road sections.  The project
            also includes components for coastal protection, road safety
            improvements, and an action plan to reduce railway deficits.
            Additionally, the project aims to finance technical
            assistance to improve transport planning, for manpower
            development and training and for the preparation of a set of
            policy actions including a study of road user charges to
            improve road pricing policy.
